summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney to Judge Loretta Preska regarding the unsealing process in a civil case. The attorney requests a temporary stay of unsealing due to new information learned on August 7, 2020, that impacts both the civil action and the criminal case against Maxwell. The letter also discusses proposed modifications to streamline the unsealing protocol and lists specific motions proposed for review.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in both the civil action (15 Civ. 7433) and the criminal case (20 Cr. 330). Her counsel is requesting a stay of the unsealing process due to new information affecting her rights.

persons.name: Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: The judge presiding over the civil case (15 Civ. 7433) to whom this letter is addressed, regarding the unsealing order and protocol.

persons.name: Laura A. Menninger
persons.context: Attorney from Haddon, Morgan and Foreman representing Ghislaine Maxwell, who authored and signed this letter to Judge Preska.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell (20 Cr. 330). The letter references seeking modification of a protective order from Judge Nathan.

persons.name: Sharon Churcher
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of a motion to quash a subpoena (Docket Entry 215) that is proposed for unsealing review.

persons.name: Doe 1
persons.context: A non-party whose deposition is subject to a stay by the Second Circuit. The letter discusses obtaining new contact information for this individual and their right to notification.

connections.description: Menninger is identified as counsel for Ms. Maxwell, representing her in the civil unsealing proceedings and corresponding with the court on her behalf.
Preska is the presiding judge in Maxwell's civil case, to whom Maxwell's counsel is submitting requests regarding the unsealing process.
Judge Nathan is presiding over Maxwell's parallel criminal case (20 Cr. 330). Maxwell's counsel intends to seek modification of a protective order from Judge Nathan.

events.title: Discovery of New Information
events.description: Counsel for Ghislaine Maxwell learned of critical new information that impacts both the civil action and the criminal case, implicating her due process rights and rights under the Fourth, Fifth, and Sixth Amendments.

events.title: Court's Unsealing Order
events.description: The Court issued an order (Doc. 1069) related to the unsealing process, which this letter is in response to.

events.title: Court's Unsealing Order
events.description: The Court issued an unsealing order that is under review by the Second Circuit.

locations: United States District Court for the Southern District of New York
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense counsel learned of critical new information on August 7, 2020, that affects both her civil and criminal cases, but cannot disclose it due to a protective order in the criminal action.
Maxwell's counsel requests a temporary stay of the unsealing process for approximately three weeks to address the protective order issue and formally present the new information to the court.
The parties agreed to some modifications to streamline the unsealing protocol, including notifying all non-parties at once and shortening some response deadlines.
The letter proposes reviewing five specific decided motions for unsealing that do not involve materials subject to the Second Circuit's stay on deposition transcripts.
Counsel references obtaining new contact information for 'Doe 1' from a separate civil suit and asserts this individual retains a right to notification.
